subject: More Announcements to consider - time sensitive
content:
On behalf of Emory’s Women in STEM organization, You are invited to their annual Networking Night!
 Join us on Wednesday, April 2nd, from 6-8 PMin the Math and Science Center (MSC) E208. This event will feature a panel of women professionals from STEM fields, who will share their experiences and discuss what it’s like to work in these roles, as well as their journeys as women in STEM. The event will be informal and relaxed, with pizza and refreshments provided. It’s a fantastic opportunity to meet professors, graduate students, and network with others in our community.
If you’re interested in attending, please RSVP here: https://tr.ee/v9QfhkjLRQ
       ____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
  SUMMER RESEARCH PROGRAM: AI Xperience 
Emory’s Center for AI Learning invites students toapply to AI.Xperience, its summer applied research program.In this program, students will have the opportunity to grow their data science and programming skills with hands-on learning. To be selected, students need to:·
	•	Have been enrolled in classes in the spring 2025 semester and be enrolled at Emory in the fall 2024 semester
	•	Attend 3 or 4 team meetings per week
	•	Be able to commit roughly 20 hours per week to the project over the 6-week period
	•	Have knowledge of common statistical analysis and machine learning methods
	•	Have experience programming in R and/or PythonAll interested students should applyby 11:59 PM on March 29, 2025.We look forward to reviewing your applications!
APPLY
 
             Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University
Email: shanna9@emory.edu | 470-620-7981
(she/her/hers)

  APPLICATIONS ARE OPEN TO JOIN THE QTM DEPARTMENT AMBASSADORS TEAM FOR AY 2025 - 26. 
 QTM Ambassadors are a selective cohort of sophomores, juniors, and seniors who are committed to service and leadership in the QTM community. As the department's student representatives, Ambassadors will engage with our external advisory board, assist with programming, andcultivate professional skills and relationships that will prove to be valuable long after graduation.
 Here are a few requirements and opportunities:
 	•	Must be a QTM major or QTM minor
	•	Must have a strong sense of responsibility
	•	Must be available to meet on Fridays for 1 hour at least twice a month between the hours of 3:00 PM – 4:30 PM

	•	Support faculty and staff with QTM events

     ANNOUNCEMENT
 Message for rising seniors who may be interested in applying for our CMBC Undergraduate Fellowship.
The Center for Mind, Brain, and Culture invites undergraduates to apply for our interdisciplinary research fellowship. This fellowship provides undergraduate researchers with intellectual and professional development opportunities through participation in the vibrant, interdisciplinary intellectual community of the Center.
 Students awarded the CMBC undergraduate fellowship will:
· Participate in regular networking lunches
· Interact with CMBC graduate certificate students and core faculty · Enjoy special access to CMBC events and visiting scholars
· Be eligible to request up to $500 in funding for interdisciplinary research and/or conference participation
Students apply in the spring of their junior year for award in the senior year. The fellowship is yearlong, beginning at
the start of the fall semester and running through the last day of spring classes. Priority will be given to students 
conducting research(literature or data based; e.g. honors projects, research partners, and independent studies) 
in an area relevant to mind, brain, or culture.
 Eligibility
· Eligible applicants include all Emory undergraduate students
· Applicants must be in their junior year seeking senior year fellowship support
Application Deadline - Monday, April 28, 2025 (last day of classes)
Notification Date - Thursday, May 1, 2025  Additional details and instructions for application submission may be found on our website.  If you have further questions about the application process, please contact CMBC Program Coordinator, Tamara Beck.  Center for Mind, Brain, and Culture
36 Eagle Row, #464
Atlanta, GA 30322
(404) 727-1134
cmbc@emory.edu
http://www.cmbc.emory.edu/
         ANOUNCEMENT
  The priority deadline to apply to be a STEM mentor for Georgia Science Education Initiative's (GSEI)summer Data Detective program is this Friday! If you are staying on campus over the summer, 
this is a great opportunity to gain volunteer hours, work with middle school students, and connect
with Winship faculty.
 GSEI is led by Dr. Theresa Gillespie of Winship Cancer Institute and runs STEM outreach programs
that aim to provide meaningful health and data science education in the classroom and in the community.The programs are supported by the National Institutes of Health, National Institutes of 
General Medicine Sciences, and the NIH Office of Data Science Strategy through a Science Education Partnership Award Grant (R25GM146271).
 GSEI's Data Detectives Summer Academyoffers middle school girls a unique opportunity to explore real cancer data and tackle community health challenges using Big Data, Artificial Intelligence, and biomedical research. The program will be held at Emory University June 2-6 and July 14-18, 2025, from 9 AM to 3 PM daily.Participants will attend engaging lectures from Emory Winship faculty, work closely with STEM mentors, and gain hands-on experience in data science and epidemiology. STEM mentors will help run small-group discussions and workshops.
 Apply here: https://www.ga-science.org/dd-stem-mentors-sign-up
 Address any questions to info@ga-science.org
  See attached flyer for details
     ANOUNCEMENT FOR GRADUATING SENIORS
 The Institute for Research in the Social Sciences (IRISS) at Stanford runs a program for recent undergraduate degree recipients who want to participate in social science research projects. Political Science faculty will lead several of the projects, and faculty from other departments will offering other opportunities (for details, click here).
 In addition to the goal of advancing research, the IRiSS Predoctoral Research Fellowship Program is intended to:
· create opportunities for predocs to deepen their knowledge of social science topics and methods, learn about options for advanced study, and build mentoring relationships to help launch their careers; and · diversify the pipeline into academia and industry.
Applications for these one-year and two-year paid research fellowship positions are now being accepted. We would be grateful for your help in informing your graduating seniors and recent students with bachelor’s degrees about this new opportunity.
 Submitted by Dr. Joe Sutherland

subject: FALL 2025  QTM 302W COURSE SIGN UP
content:
Hello,
 You are receiving this email because you filled out the form for the FALL 2025 QTM 302W course. Please know that by filling out the form only lets us know you are interested in being considered for a permission code to register for one of the QTM 302W courses. Filling out the form does not guarantee you will receive a permission code. Dr. Jin Kim, Director of Undergraduate Studies(DUS) for the QTM Department will decide who will get a permission code for the course. Per the professors’ request, graduating seniors will be given preference. Permission codes will be send out to selected students after March 28th Advising meeting which is at 1:15 PM – 2:30 PM in the PAIS 290. Permission codes will be sent to those selected via email before March 31st. The Advising Meeting is very important especially for those of you who have not been assigned a QTM advisor yet. So please be in attendance. If you have questions, please reach out. Thanks. 
 HERE ARE OTHER OPTIONS TO TAKE QTM 302W COURSES IN THE SUMMER 2025 ( no permission code required - see atlas for more details about the course)

subject: Very Important meeting on March 28th at 1:15 PM for All QTM Students
content:
Hi QTM Students,
 It is that time of year again right before pre-registration for Fall 2025 and time to get clarity regarding pre-requisites, new courses, and degree requirements. On Friday, March 28th at 1:15 PM – 2:30 PM in the PAIS Building in room 290, we will be having an Advising Meeting with Dr. Jin Kim, Dr. Kevin McAlister and Dr. Allison Cuttner. So please bring your general questions and concerns regarding your course selections and course requirements. This meeting is very important. So please be in attendance and on time. 
 Dr. Jin Kim will be clarifying pre-requisite requirements, course substitutions, course exception request ( QTM 151, QTM 210, QTM 220 , etc.) and answering questions.   Dr. McAlister and Dr. Cuttner will also be available for you to ask questions regarding the Honors program, internships, Research opportunities, Capstone, AI Data Lab, etc.   Some of you who recently declared your major or minor and were not assigned an advisor yet, you especially need to be in attendance at this meeting as you will have the opportunity to be advised by these advisors/faculty, ask questions and get answers. 
  Special Announcement
 Summer 2025 – there is another QTM 302W – section 2 - Technical Writing course added to the summer 2025 schedule taught by Dr. Ben Miller - see: https://atlas.emory.edu/ for more details.

 Submitted by Dr. Cliff Carrubba
   ANNOUNCEMENT
   Data Science for Social Good 
Data Science for Social Good is happening on February 23rd at the Emory Student Center! This exciting event will explore the intersection between data science and affordable housing in Atlanta.  Join us for a day of expert-led talks and a hands-on data science workshop to uncover insights on the affordable housing issue in Atlanta and across the country. You'll hear from data scientists and housing experts on biased algorithms in housing, Georgia's eviction crisis, and how to empower social change using data science and analytics. A professional data analyst also guide you through a geospatial mapping and regression modeling workshop using real housing data. Free food will be provided for all attendees!  Registration form:https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSesiLrNUKawPFhMfR-IsZZsdcs9Z8heonO9zc_ovmW9SPcmDA/viewform?usp=sf_link
         OPPORTUNITY
  Message from the Emory Artificial Intelligence and Data Association(EmoryAIDA). 
 We are excited to host an upcoming panel discussion, "Future of AI in Healthcare: From Diagnosis to Personalized Treatment," featuring esteemed Emory faculty, including Dr. Ruoxuan Xiong from the QTM Department. This event will explore AI's impact on diagnostics, patient care, and hyper-personalized treatments, with engaging discussions and interactive Q&A sessions.
 Event Details
📅Date: February 24, 2025
🕠Time: 16:30 - 18:00
📍Location: Atlanta Campus MSC E208
 Given the interdisciplinary nature of the event, we believe it may be of interest to students and faculty in the QTM Department. If possible, we would greatly appreciate any assistance in sharing the event with the department—whether through a mention in the QTM Department newsletter, a general email announcement, or posting the flyer in the PAIS building. Of course, we completely understand if that is not feasible.

SENIORS 
      Hello Romantics,

   ANNOUNCEMENT
 
  Data Science for Social Good 
Data Science for Social Good is happening on February 23rd at the Emory Student Center! This exciting event will explore the intersection between data science and affordable housing in Atlanta.  Join us for a day of expert-led talks and a hands-on data science workshop to uncover insights on the affordable housing issue in Atlanta and across the country. You'll hear from data scientists and housing experts on biased algorithms in housing, Georgia's eviction crisis, and how to empower social change using data science and analytics. A professional data analyst also guide you through a geospatial mapping and regression modeling workshop using real housing data. Free food will be provided for all attendees!  Registration form:https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSesiLrNUKawPFhMfR-IsZZsdcs9Z8heonO9zc_ovmW9SPcmDA/viewform?usp=sf_link
         OPPORTUNITY
  EDSC Projects
Ready to apply your analytical skills to gain real-world data science experience? Apply to join one of EDSC's research projects to tackle real problems across various fields of interest (economics, environmental science, coastal hazards, cardiovascular diagnostics, and business operations). Project teams work together for a semester, with opportunities for poster presentations and networking at the end.

     ANNOUNCEMENT 
 The CS Department is excited to announce that we are waiving CS 4+1 Application Fees this year! The CS 4+1 program allows Emory undergraduates to obtain a BA/BS from Emory College in four years and a CS MS degree from the Laney Graduate School in one extra year. The application deadline for current juniors is March 31st. 
      
       ANNOUNCEMENT
  Hi Sociology students — the below message from Dr. Simonds of GSU may be of interest....  The Gerontology Institute at GSU offers an intimate, nurturing, and stimulating environment in which to learn. Information on our programs can be found here.For detailed information on program requirements and courses, please see our Graduate Student Handbook.  The 36-credit MA in Gerontologyleads to stableemployment for our graduates,who go on to serveolder adults through employment in direct service, governmental, and non-governmental organizations. Approximatelyone-fourth go on to earn PhDs in Gerontology, Sociology, and other related fields.  We admit students for the MA program once a year to begin in the Fall term.Thedeadline for Fall 2025 MA applications is March 1.We admit Certificate students in both Fall and Spring terms. The deadlines for Certificate applications is July 1 (for Fall) and November 15 (for Spring).
 We offer a few graduate assistantships each year to MA students; these include a tuition waiver and a small stipend ($7200) across the year in exchange for working 8 hours/week with a professor. We do not offer Graduate Assistantships to Certificate students.  The application is comprised of:a brief statement of interest(wherein applicants describe why they want to pursue a certificate or MA in Gerontology, their passion for the field, and/or their research interests), three letters of reference, and transcripts.We do not require theGRE.You may begin your application here.  Our 18-credit Certificate program offers a specialized credential in Gerontology for professionals or graduate students in other fields.Thisprogram typically takes one year to complete.  Our 9-credit Certificate in Leadership and Aging is designed for people who are already working in the field in some way, who would like to gain knowledge in the field as well as a credential.
 Allcredits earned in our Certificate programs may be applied toourMA degree.
 Interested studentsare welcome tocontact me directlywith questions about the programs or the application process: wsimonds@gsu.edu.

       Opportunity
AON Corporation 
Opportunity for Sophomores only
The Sophomore Actuarial Mentor Program connects students with experienced professionals in the field to provide guidance, career insights, and networking opportunities. It’s designed to help students explore the actuarial profession, understand some of the paths to becoming an actuary, and build meaningful connections early in their academic journey. We also give participants that are engaged and interested an opportunity to apply and interview for roles early for our Summer 2026 actuarial opportunities.
 We work to pair students with mentors in the office location/line of work that they are most interested in exploring for future opportunities.

subject: SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT
content:
SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT
 Emory's Center for AI Learning is now accepting applications to participate in the Spring 2025 AI. Data Lab program!
 AI.DataLab is a 10 week, data micro-consulting project hosted by the Center for AI Learning where students will work in teams to solve real-world problems with data. Each team will gain exposure to the world of professional data analytics by tackling issues presented by companies in the Atlanta area and developing data-driven solutions for them. For this iteration, students will have the opportunity to work with the following organizations:
	•	TechBridge (TB): TB is a non-profit whose mission is to alleviate generational poverty by equipping other non-profits with enterprise-grade software and technology. Students will investigate and leverage over 18+ years of transactional national data to improve the foundational algorithm for TB's flagship software addressing hunger relief.
	•	Sustainability Office (SO): The Emory Sustainability Office is interested in invoking sustainability into AI practices. This project will task students to creatively brainstorm how to approach either better understanding energy usage of AI, how to inform users of their individual AI tool behaviors' impact on energy, and/or how Emory could measure and report on sustainable AI practices.
	•	Emory Department of Chemistry (C): Over the last 10 years, the Department of Chemistry has revamped its curriculum to improve the experience of Chemistry majors. After collecting a large amount of evaluation and survey data, this AI.DataLab project will analyze the success of the curriculum overhaul and pitch how the department can continue to improve. 	•	InvestAtlanta (IA): IA is a local government authority for Atlanta focused on the economic and equitable improvement of the city. Students will conduct a sentiment analysis of governmental-adjacent agencies, like InvestAtlanta, to understand public perception of agencies that work in this industry.
Students with all kinds of experience levels are encouraged to apply. However, selected students will be expected to be able to work with Python in order to perform analysis. Teams will be created in such a way to induce the greatest experiential diversity within each team as to allow those with less experience to learn from students with more background in programming. Undergraduate students are eligible to receive 1 credit hour in INTERN496R to achieve their Experience & Application (XA) credit for their participation.
All participants in the AI.DataLab program will be expected to attend weekly meetings on Thursdays from 6:00 - 7:30 in White Hall. These meetings are meant to provide students with a common time and location to work with their teams. Topics can range from soft skills, such as data storytelling, to hard skills like string processing. Therefore, students applying must have this block of time free in their weekly schedule --at least two-thirds of these weekly meetings must be attended to earn a Pass/Satisfactory grade, and/or to be credited in final deliverables. If this time does not work for you, AI.DataLab will be offered in subsequent semesters and you are encouraged to apply for later iterations.
 Applications are due by 5:00 p.m. on Tuesday, January 21.The first weekly meeting will take place at 6:00PM on January 30th. If you have any questions, please reach out to tottoli@emory.edu.
 The application can be found here: https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=nPsE4KSwT0K80DImBtXfONoMV0zVh_FDuG1Bf6CV029UNzhRNFUwMUM2SUxOSzhYSDBBVDYxSk9OUC4u.
  Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University
Email: shanna9@emory.edu | 470-620-7981

     Announcement 
    
  Do you have an early-stage startup that you want to rapidly move forward? Apply now to the Techstars Emory Founder Catalyst-(Due Jan 17, 2025). This spring, the Startup Launch Accelerator is evolving into The Techstars Emory Founder Catalyst.
The Techstars Emory Founder Catalyst is a 10-week pre-accelerator program providing early-stage for-profit entrepreneurs with invaluable startup education and mentorship from one of the top accelerators in the world.
The Techstars Emory Founder Catalyst might be right for you if you have:Domain expertiseYou possess deep understanding or unique insight into the challenge your startup is addressing.A clear problem to solveYou have identified a well-defined customer need and have a lead on the solution.Raised less than $1MFounders of early- or idea-stage companies raised less than $1M will receive the most benefit from the program structure and activities.

  TEDxEmory will host its main conferencethis year on February 22nd, 2025.  Our conference brings leaders, experts, and professionals from all over the world to give TED talks at Emory. Currently, we have an executive at Georgia Public Broadcasting, a Paralympic gold medalist, and a high-profile Neurosurgeon/Influencerin the lineup.  In addition to 10 professional speakers, the conference features TWO EMORY STUDENT SPEAKERSfrom undergraduate and graduate schools.  The talks are professionally recorded and posted on the official TED YouTube website. Our talks have millions of views and hundreds of people attend our conference! This is a wonderful opportunity to network with professionals from around the country and to share ideas with a wider audience.
 This event encourages the exchange of professionally workshopped and developed ideas between students, faculty, and professionals. This is a unique opportunity for students from your department to share their knowledge, passion, and research in their fields.  If you know of any students in your network who may have valuable insights to share, we would greatly appreciate it if you could help us spread the word and encourage them to apply by sharing the message above.
 Link to the application form: https://forms.gle/VEs7dDbL2TFhRJjy6
Check out some of our past TEDxEmory Conferences: https://www.tedxemory.org/
 Thank you for your time and consideration in supporting TEDxEmory
 If you have any questions, please reach out to isabella.aguado@emory.edu
     OPPORTUNITY
  The Marcus Autism Center, in conjunction with the Emory University School of Medicine and Children's Healthcare of Atlanta, is offering five fellowships: the Cohen Fellowship in Developmental Social Neuroscience, the Simons Fellowship in Computational Neuroscience, the Louise and Brett Samsky Fellowship in Educational Science and Practice, the Sally Provence Fellowship in Clinical Research, and the ACCESS Fellowship in Implementation Science. 
Students who will receive a bachelor's degree by June 2025 will be eligible for the positions. The fellowships will commence in July 2025, and they are 2 years in duration. Students can find further details here. 
Attached, please find a brochure describing the fellowships. Please feel free to print the brochure and post it in your department. I ask that you let us know that you have received this e-mail and that you forward it, along with the associated brochure, to students in the Department of Quantitative Theory and Methods. 
The Cohen Fellowship in Developmental Social Neuroscience will involve cutting-edge social neuroscience and/or neuroimaging research in infants, toddlers and adolescents. Fellows will work to further the understanding of autism through eye-tracking research, guiding a project from the point of data collection to publication of results. 
The Simons Fellowship in Computational Neuroscience will involve integrating computational strategies with clinical research goals. Fellows will develop methods for the analysis of visual scanning and eye-tracking data, computational models of visual salience, and data visualization techniques, all with the aim of advancing the understanding of autism and efforts at early diagnosis. 
The Louise and Brett Samsky Fellowship in Educational Science and Practice will involve research in educational innovations in autism. Fellows will learn about classroom-based interventions to increase social emotional engagement and inclusion, gaining experiences with observational research methods, practical experience through direct classroom responsibilities, cutting edge intervention research, and implementation science approaches. 
The Sally Provence Fellowship in Clinical Research will select fellows for a two-year training in clinical assessment measures and research methodologies to better understand ASD and related disabilities. 
The ACCESS Fellowship in Implementation Science will select fellows for a two-year training in research focused on community engagement participatory methods, translating evidence-based treatments for autism into community settings, as well as the processes and partnerships that support these efforts. 
Thank you for your help! We look forward to hearing from you. 
Sincerely, Marcus Predoctoral Fellowship Committee 

Marcus Autism Center, Children's Healthcare of Atlanta, & Emory University School of Medicine Phone: 404-785-9554 Email: marcus.predoc-fellowships@emory.edu

 Please subscribe to the QSS-bio listserv, if you are not on it yet, to receive track-specific messages, with these two steps:

 Submitted by Dr. Michal Arbilly
      Greetings,  The MARC Undergraduate Scholars Program is now accepting applications for our 2025-2026 cohort!
 In short, the Maximizing Student Access to Research Careers (MARC) Undergraduate Scholars Program is a NIH-funded, two-year research and academic program for undergraduate scholars in STEM research. The program focuses on multi-level mentoring, research integrity, and career preparation to nurture students to become successful graduates from high-caliber Ph.D. programs in the biomedical and behavioral sciences fields. Moreover, selected MARC Scholars receive up to $16,000 in tuition, a $14,340 stipend, and a $1000 travel award to attend scientific meetings annually!  The deadline for the MARC Undergraduate Scholar Application and required Faculty Recommendation Questionnaire, which will automatically be sent directly to the recommender, is Friday, December 20th, 2024, at 11:59 pm.Students can access the MARC Undergraduate Scholar Application via College Connect. After signing onto College Connect with an Emory NetID, students should click the Application Center to find the MARC Undergraduate Scholar Application under the Undergraduate Research Programs category.
 If you have any questions, feel free to contact the Associate Director, Kristen Walden, via email (kawalde@emory.edu).
 Flyer and application attached
  Submitted by Kristen A. Walden, PhD
   
 The University of Bath UK is seeking a highly motivated PhD student with career goals in medical statistics.  Successful applicant will be working on a fully funded project, titledIncorporating Covariate Information to Design and Analyse Precision Medicine Clinical Trials, supervised by Dr Haiyan Zheng.
An overview of the project can be found athttps://www.findaphd.com/phds/project/?p176735Industrial partner: This project will benefit from collaboration with Dr Michael Grayling (Senior Principal Statistician, Johnson & Johnson), a statistical expert with extensive experience in adaptive designs for clinical trials. Dr Grayling will join the supervision meetings on a regular basis and will in particular provide industry-linked expertise on the practicality of statistical methods developed from this project. Project keywords: Bayesian statistics, borrowing of information, covariate, experimental design, mixture model, subgroupClosing date: 12 January 2025Funding note: This project is directly funded by the University of Bath for entry in September 2025, and the studentship is tenable for 3 years. Funding covers tuition fees,a stipend (£19,237 p/a in 2024/5) and access to a £1,000 training support budget.Non-UK applicants must meet the programme’s English language requirement by the application deadline.
Informal enquiries about this post or project may be made to Dr Haiyan Zheng: hz2075 (at) bath (dot) ac (dot) uk

A four year fully funded PhD studentship is available at Warwick Medical School, University of Warwick, as part of the MRC Doctoral Training Partnership.  The program involves a one-year MSc in Interdisciplinary Biomedical Research, followed by a three-year PhD project co-supervised by Professor Nigel Stallard (Warwick Clinical Trials Unit) and Dr Cornelia Ursula Kunz (Global Statistics and Data Science Unit, Boehringer Ingelheim, Germany) focussing on Innovative statistical methods for dose-finding in clinical drug development. The student will spend at least 3 months at the Boehringer Ingelheim site in Biberach an der Riss (Germany).

     Omicron Delta Kappa, the National Leadership Honor Society, recognizes and encourages superior leadership and exemplary character. Founded in 1914, O∆K encourages collaboration among members across five pillars of leadership: academics and research, athletics, service to campus and community, communications, and creative and performing arts.
 The Emory University chapter of Omicron Delta Kappa was founded in 1925 and strives to foster excellence in service, research, academics, athletics, and the performing arts. Applications are open to current juniors, seniors, and graduate students, and requirements include a minimum 3.6 GPA and a significant demonstration of leadership on campus.
 Applicants should start at the Apply for Membership page, which provides instructions for 1) creating an account and 2) applying for membership using that account.
 Please complete the following items to complete your application for Emory University’s chapter of ODK:  National ODK Application: https://odk.org/members/apply-for-membership/
 Emory University ODK Application: https://forms.gle/8RMJJmudisNoT4in8
 Both application components are due on November 15th, 2024. Your application will not be considered if both elements are not completed!!    Submitted by Ataelfadeel Mohamed

content:
For QTM Undergraduates

Friday, October 25, 2024




     

  INVITATION FROM TH ENGLISH DEPARTMENT 
  The English Department will be having an amazing third annual Halloween party. All majors are welcome! There will be food and giveaways! Students are asked to RSVP by October 28th. Please contact the program coordinator, Khristin Isley directly should you have any additional questions. 
 Thank you! 
-------------------------------------------------------
 *Friendly Reminder*
 Dear Majors and Minors,
 
 We cast a spell to invite you to join us! It's time for the English Department's Annual Halloween party—don't be a broom and miss out! We’ll have a friendly competition for the best literary character costume and lots of frightfully delicious food on hand.
 Where: Kemp Malone Library (Callaway N301)
When: Thursday, October 31st
Time: 3-5 PM
 Prepare yourself for a day of games, good food, and fun! Come alone or bring some friends! All majors are welcome!
 -Refreshments and Bites provided-
 RSVP IF YOU "Witch"
RSVP “YES” to Khristin.isley@emory.eduand subject Third (Annual) English DepartmentHalloweenPartyby noon, no later than Monday, October 28th, to ensure we purchase enough food and candy👻🕷🎃👻!
 
 
 
    Delta Phi Lambda, an Asian-interest sorority is hosting a career development event designed to support women of color! 
 Come join this empowering resource discovery event on November 7th from 6-8pm in Harland Cinema. At the event students can:
* Get free professional headshots (first 50 RSVPs)
* Receive resume, LinkedIn, and interview tips from women leaders
* Network with professional women in healthcare, STEM, business, academia, and nonprofits
* Gain insider advice for succeeding as a woman of color
* Enjoy refreshments and connect with your peers
Whether students are looking to step up their professional brand, expand their network, or get guidance from inspirational role models, this career exploration event has them covered. Space is limited; we highly encourage attendees to reserve their spot today (RSVP Link: https://forms.gle/JURTNqqv2Z3kDL6H7)!   submitted by Erin Koo, Emory University
 
    COPSS-NISS Leadership Webinar: Leadership in Linking Statistical Theory and Scientific Inquiry
Date& Time: Tuesday, October 29, 2024 - 12:00pmto 1:00pm ET
Event Page: https://www.niss.org/events/copss-niss-leadership-webinar-leadership-linking-statistical-theory-and-scientific-inquiry
Zoom Registration Link:us02web.zoom.us/webinar/register/...
 Overview:Join us for an insightful webinar exploring the role of leadership in bridging statistical theory with scientific inquiry. This event, co-hosted by COPSS and NISS, brings together distinguished leaders in statistics and data science to discuss the critical intersections of theory, research, and practice. Attendees will gain valuable perspectives on how statistical methodologies drive innovation and shape scientific progress across various disciplines. This is a must-attend event for statisticians, researchers, and professionals looking to enhance their leadership and impact in the field.
Speakers
Michael R. Kosorok, PhD, W.R. Kenan, Jr. Distinguished Professor of Biostatistics, Professor of Statistics and Operations Research, and Director of the Gillings School Center for AI and Public Health, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.
Daniela Witten,Professor of Statistics and Biostatistics at University of Washington, and the Dorothy Gilford Endowed Chair in Mathematical Statistics.
Moderator
Anru Zhang, Professor, Departments of Biostatistics & Bioinformatics and Computer Science & Departments of Statistical Science, Electrical & Computer Engineering, and Mathematics, Duke University.
Register on Zoom Here!
  About the COPSS-NISS Leadership Webinar Series
COPSS (Committee of the Presidents of Statistical Societies) and NISS have come together to organize and host a new webinar series focusing on leadership in statistics and data science. Plan to attend these webinars every month during the academic year!Visit the COPSS-NISS Leadership Series Pagefor previous webinars.
The COPSS-NISS Leadership Webinar Series is co-organized by the Committee of the Presidentsof Statistical Societies (COPSS) Emerging Leaders in Statisticsand the National Institute ofStatistical Sciences (NISS). The purpose of the webinar series is to promote leadership skills formembers of the statistical societies at any stage in their careers. The series features conversations with leaders throughout the discipline, including leaders from major academic and government institutions, and companies. Invited speakers share their leadership stories and answer questions about their experiences. Each webinar is moderated by a member of the COPSS Emerging Leaders in Statistics program.
Access the Full COPSS-NISS Leadership Webinar Series YouTube Playlist | COPSS-NISS Leadership Webinar Series:www.youtube.com/...

subject: Opportunity today
content:
ANNOUNCEMENT
 The National Consortium for Data Science (NCDS) is pleased to announce the next Foundations of AI course. AI for Non-Coders, taught by Amy Hemmeter, will take place on Thursday, September 26 at 1 PM ET.Foundations of AI will fulfill the NCDS mission to connect diverse communities of data science experts to support a 21st century data-driven economy by creating a data-literate workforce and bridging the gap between data scientists in the public and private sectors requires educational and upskilling opportunities. A limited number of full scholarship opportunities will be available on a case-by-case basis. Please contact Amanda Miller for more information.
 We would greatly appreciate any help you could provide to promote this event to staff, students, faculty, and community members who may be interested. 
 I’ve attached graphics and have included additional information below. Please let me know if you have any questions, and thank you in advance for your review.
  Foundations of AI: AI for Non-Coders | September 26 at 1 PM ET
Ever say to yourself: what even is an LLM? How do I get from chatting with ChatGPT to talking about larger AI products? How do I answer these nonstop questions from colleagues, customers, leadership and more in this new landscape? Do you find yourself needing expertise on AI that, quite frankly, you didn’t sign up for? This course is designed to meet the needs of people who are not necessarily well-versed in math and science but who know that they need to know the basics about AI in this changing landscape. You’ll learn about what AI can accomplish, the intuitions behind how it works (no math or coding necessary!), and opportunities and risks. You’ll come away feeling confident that you know not only what an LLM actually is, but understand all the jargon people use to talk about it. Scholarships are available on a case-by-case basis.
 Those interested in the event can register directly at this link: https://bit.ly/AI_NonCoders_NCDS.    Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University
Email: shanna9@emory.edu | 470-620-7981
(she/her/hers)

subject: OPPORTUNITTY ANNOUNCEMENTS- WEEK OF 9/16/2024
content:
OPPORTUNITY ANNOUNCEMENTS THIS WEEK
  The Editorial Board at Emory needs you!
 The Editorial Board is a diverse group of opinion journalists who articulate the Wheel’s opinion on issues important to the Emory community. Being a part of this team provides students with or without a background in journalism a fantastic opportunity to think critically about a wide variety of current events and work collaboratively to draft articles about them. Our past work (see herefor examples) has won regional and national awards from the Society of Professional Journalists and administrators regularly read our coverage.
 Each week, we meet twice (Wednesdays and Sundays)—once to brainstorm article topics and debate our collective position on them and once to group-edit the articles that arise from those discussions—and publish 1-2 articles. If you are interested, our application (this Microsoft Form) is due at 11:59pm on September 18.
 If you have any questions, feel free to reach out to me at marc.goedemans@emory.edu Thank you very much for your time and consideration. We look forward to hearing from you soon!
   OPPORTUNITY FOR SCHOLOARSHIP FOR JUNIORS
 The National Scholarships and Fellowships Program is excited to announce an upcoming Beinecke Info Session on Wednesday, September 18thfrom 11:30am-12:30pm in Tarbutton 120Ahosted by Dr. Matthew Loar, Director of the Beinecke Scholarship Program. The Beinecke Scholarship provides $30,000 throughout graduate school and an additional $5,000 stipend upon being selected as a recipient. Emory's most recent recipient of this highly competitive award was sociology major Courtney Fitzgerald '25C, who was selected this summer as one of just 20 Beinecke Scholars across the U.S. To be eligible for this opportunity, students must be:  · Juniors
· Planning to pursue a master’s or Doctoral program in the Arts, Humanities or Social Sciences
· U.S. Citizens or U.S. National
· Eligible for need-based financial aid (with a preference for Pell Grant recipients)
For more info about this award, including more recent recipients, visit our website. We’re eager to spread the word to as many eligible and interested students as possible and would greatly appreciate it if you could share this message.
If there are any questions or additional information required, do not hesitate to reach out to us directly at ec.nationalawards@emory.edu.
  MBA PROGRAM INFORMATION
 
MIT Sloan will be joining other top business schools in-person at Atlanta’s Insight into Deferred Enrollment Programs on Wednesday, September 18, 2024. We hope to connect with high-potential students from Emory University at this event. 
Please share this email with those in your student communities who may be interested. You can also download our MBA Earlyfact sheet to share with students and learn more about our deferred admissions offering on our website. 
Theevent will feature a moderated conversation with admissions representatives as well as a chance to network with each participating university.
  The 2024 International Education Week Essay Contest
For those of you who are not yet aware, staff from ISSS, GSI and other offices across Emory have been organizing events and activities to promote International Education Week (IEW) at Emory the week of November 18th. You can find details about what is scheduled so far here, and this site will be updated as events are added. We hope that you will attend events of interest and promote them as well.
 As part of IEW, we are excited to share that the 2024 International Education Week Essay Contest is now open for submissions! The contest, which runs until Sunday, October 6th at 11:59pm EST,encourages all currently enrolled Emory students to submit a 500-750 word essay on the impact global experiences have made on their time at Emory, whether in Atlanta or elsewhere in the world.  There will be two first place prizes of $500 for undergraduate and graduate essays respectively, and two additional runner-up prizes of$250 for each category. All rules and guidelines are accessible on the website, where students can also access the form to submit their essay. Winners and runners-up will be invited to read their essays during an event during International Education Week.
 Please find attached the official contest flyer, which we encourage you to share with your networks and the wider Emory community.

subject: Special Announcement
content:
SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT
From Alexander Tolbert 
QTM Department faculty
  I'm excited to announce the launch of the Tolbert-Black Digital Research Lab (BDRL-ATL) at Emory University, focused on preserving and advancing Black history, philosophy, theology, culture, and art in Atlanta through digital humanities and AI technologies.
 The Lab is building a comprehensive digital archive of Black intellectual, cultural, and artistic contributions in Atlanta, including texts, oral histories, visual art, literature, and music. We support interdisciplinary research that explores the impact of Black thought on social justice movements and contemporary debates, ensuring that cultural expressions are accessible for future scholarship and public engagement.
 We offer training programs for Black students from the Atlanta metro area and HBCUs, equipping them with skills in coding, digital humanities, AI, and LLMs, preparing them for leadership in academia, technology, and public history.
 A key focus of our work is extracting "thick data" from archival research and ethnographic studies to inform the design of AI systems and the development of Black-centered datasets and ethical AI frameworks.
 Our Risk-Informed Design Pipeline identifies and addresses potential harms in AI development, ensuring that AI models are accurate and socially responsible. We also develop and curate datasets that reflect Black experiences, contributing to the creation of fair and robust AI models.
 Signature projects include the Atlanta Black Philosophy, Theology, and Art Archive, the Thick Data Collection Initiative, Black-Centered Algorithmic Fairness, and Mapping Black Atlanta, an interactive digital map of significant sites in the city’s Black history.
 Please share this with any interested students. They can learn more about the Lab and opportunities by visiting our website. https://sites.google.com/view/alextolbertlab/about”
  Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University

subject: GREAT INTERNSHIP OPPORTUNITY
content:
GREAT INTERNSHIP OPPORTUNITY
 
 
 
Science for Georgia is looking for 1-3 interns for the Fall 2024 semester.
Students will gain in-depth understanding of the Science for Georgia Data Analytics Program by contributing to a specific data-for-good story.  The data analysis program is centered on using existing environmental and social data to produce contextualized data stories about the physical, economic and environmental health of Georgia communities. 
 
Gain hands-on experience in storytelling with data, utilizing real world “messy” data, and being part of a project and data management process. 
 
The goal is for the intern to become a “Project Manager” of a data team during a Spring QTM Capstone project class. The product of the QTM Capstone will be a contextualized public-facing data story.
	•	Weekly Hours: 10-20
 
	•	Location: 100% remote. Sci4Ga has co-working space in Atlanta and interns are welcome to join us there.
 
	•	Expected Skills:
	◦	Ability to work in Excel, Python and/or R
	◦	Basic data analysis techniques
	◦	Ability to manage time in a fast-paced environment
	◦	Ability to independently carry out research tasks
	◦	Some previous experience working with geospatial data and GIS software like ArcGIS or GeoPandas or a strong willingness to learn!
 
A full description of the role and expectations can be seen at bit.ly/3AL5lGC
This internship will be for class credit and follow the fall semester calendar.  Students who are selected for this internship will be enrolled in QTM 496R for 3 credit hours.
 
Interested students can complete the application at https://forms.office.com/r/FZe9VrU3BT.
We will begin reviewing applications at 5:00 PM on September 5th.
 
Please email Dr. Kevin McAlister (kevin.mcalister@emory.edu) with any questions.
 
BEST,

Course title: Ethical Emerging TechnologiesDescription: This course explores the ethical implications and governance challenges of emerging technologies such as AI, autonomous vehicles, autonomous weapons, digital medicine, blockchain, sustainability and the environment, and IoT. Students will explore key pillars of ethical tech development, including explainability, fairness, bias and privacy, while also learning about the economic impact of emerging technologies such as AI.

subject: New Class Announcement
content:
NEW CLASS ANNOUNCEMENT
 
Topics in Quantitative Science: Unlocking the Future with AI
Includes topics related to statistical computing.
 
QTM 285  - Section 2,  Class # 6295
Credit Hours: 3
 
Schedule and Location:   W 4pm-7pm in ONLINE
Instruction Method: Distance Learning
 
Instructor:  Dr. Richard Pocklington 
 
Prompting and Meta Prompting: Unlocking the Future with AI -
Dive into the rapidly evolving field of AI to learn how to use the transformative techniques of prompting and meta prompting in large language models (LLMs). Gain a solid foundation in AI and LLMs fundamentals to broaden your ability to craft effective prompts to elicit desired outputs. Through hands-on projects and case studies, learn to design, optimize, and evaluate prompts for various applications (such as structured text generation and sentiment analysis). Explore advanced topics like Chain of Thought, Graph of Thought, and Tree of Thought to leverage LLMs for complex tasks. Ethical implications of LLMs will also be explored. Engage with cutting-edge research, industry experts, and real-world datasets while developing practical skills in AI frameworks and tools. By course end, be equipped to apply prompting and meta prompting across domains, making significant contributions to your chosen application area with state-of-the-art LLM applications.
To successfully complete this course, students should have completed QTM 100 Intro to Stat Inference and QTM 150 Introduction to Statistical Computing I, or equivalent coursework.
 
Best,

Emory University

subject: New Class Announcement for fall 2024
content:
NEW CLASS ANNOUNCEMENT FOR FALL 2024
 
Intensive version of QTM 220 Regression Analysis and will count for QTM 220 requirement
It is particularly useful for AMS majors and other students with a strong math background
 
 
QTM 285-1 Prediction, Inference, & Causality 
A Rigorous Introduction to Prediction, Inference, and Causality
 
MW 4pm-5:15pm  room 230 - New Psyc Bldg (36 Eagle Row)
F 2:30pm-3:20pm  room 220 - New Psyc Bldg (36 Eagle Row)
 
Instructor:  Dr. David Hirshberg
 
This class will be accepted in place of QTM 220 and there is substantial overlap in content between the two. However, there will be a greater emphasis on the precision with which we move from stories and intuition to formal mathematical reasoning--and back--in this course. Data visualization, including sketching by hand and plotting in R, will be emphasized as a tool for making this connection.
 
A modern, mathematically rigorous introduction to statistical modeling and data-driven decision-making that provides a foundation for upper-level classes in the department. We will focus on prediction---using data we have to tell us something about data we don't, statistical inference---characterizing the uncertainty we have about the accuracy of these predictions, and causal inference---understanding what the relationships we see in the data tell us about the impact of actions we might take. While the class will emphasize the intuitive and mathematical foundations of these concepts, we will also cover the implementation of these techniques in applications using the statistical programming language R.
 
To succeed in this course, students should have the same prerequisites as for QTM 220: (QTM 110 or QTM_OX 110) & (QTM 150 or QTM_OX 150) & (QTM 120 or MATH 210 or MATH_OX 210 or MATH_211 or MATH_OX 211) & [QTM 210 or QTM_OX 210 or ECON 220 or ECON_OX 220 or (MATH 361 and MATH 362)] & (MATH 221 or MATH_OX 221) or equivalent.
 
 
Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University

subject: SUMMER ANNOUNCEMENT
content:
SUMMER ANNOUNCEMENT
 
 
Invitation to the 2nd AI Summer School, Symposium and Datathon
 
Join us for the 2nd Medical Imaging, AI, and Bias Data Symposium happening from August 19 to August 25, 2024, at Emory University. The focus of this symposium is to collaboratively uncover bias, establish collaborations, and provide the opportunity to work with real data, supported by a team that understands the data. Following the success of last year’s event (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nzXoOyKlOtg), we have observed the need to bridge the communication gap between medical professionals and computer scientists. Therefore, we are dedicating four days to summarizing the common mistakes and pitfalls we have observed, using a case-based approach to learning medical imaging. 
   
During these four days, we will offer a case-based learning curriculum that spans from ICU data to Chest X-ray, as well as breast imaging data. We will also be launching EMBED2, a multi-modal breast imaging data, including 3D imaging (tomosynthesis) and MRI imaging, with improved patient outcomes.  
  
We hope you can join us. Please register here - https://www.datathon.org
 

Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University
Email: shanna9@emory.edu | 470-620-7981
(she/her/hers)

subject: Special Announcement  - Course for the Summer Session II
content:
SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT
COURSE FOR THE SUMMER SESSION II
 
QTM 499R Directed Research, section 2 (1 CR)
Large Language Models in Practice: Beyond ChatGPT 
instructor: Jo Guldi with Richard Pocklington of Thinkable Inc., Burlington, Ontario, Canada
M-F July 15-19, 9AM-12PM
In-person or remote attendance is allowed. Non-credit option is available–contact Jo Guldi (jo.guldi@emory.edu) for details of non-credit participation.
This course is designed for advanced undergraduate and graduate students. Participants should have taken QTM 100 Intro to Stat Inference and QTM 150 Introduction to Statistical Computing I or have an equivalent background in statistical inference and computing.
Dive into the rapidly evolving field of AI to learn how to use the transformative techniques of prompting and meta prompting in large language models (LLMs). Gain a foundation in AI and LLMs fundamentals to broaden your ability to craft effective prompts to elicit desired outputs. Through hands-on projects and case studies, learn to design, optimize, and evaluate prompts for various applications (such as structured text generation and sentiment analysis). Explore advanced topics like Chain of Thought, Graph of Thought, and Tree of Thought to leverage LLMs for complex tasks. Ethical implications of LLMs will also be explored. Engage with cutting-edge research, industry experts, and real-world datasets while developing practical skills in AI frameworks and tools. By course end, be equipped to apply prompting and meta prompting across domains, making significant contributions to your chosen application area with state-of-the-art LLM applications.
 
Please note that the enrollment deadline will ends for this course July 5th during add/drop/swap./
 
Best, 
 
Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University

Research Assistant 
Opportunities available to advanced undergraduate or graduate students. Please see details below and apply via Handshake at the links included in the descriptions.
 
Questions can be directed to McKenzie Beverage or Jo Guldi. 
 
Seeking Data Science Research Assistant to help with project “Text Mining the Documentation of Climate Change.” 
Apply at: https://emory.joinhandshake.com/emp/jobs/8999657 
Applicants should be a mature, independent, and self-directed, capable of asking many questions about what constitutes an ideal set of results, reporting to three faculty from QTM, Law, and Public Health. Student will be required to respond with weekly iterations to the project, booking time with faculty leads, reporting on progress and flagging issues on the way to a final project. 
 
Required skills: textual analysis using R or Python, basic knowledge of tokenization, collocation analysis, topic modeling, word embeddings.  
 
Ideal skillset: a graduate of QTM 340, Text as Data, with some skills web scraping and scraping pdf’s using Selenium. Ideally student has a background in studies in the humanities and/or social sciences, has taken classes on the interpretation of texts and the analysis of historical events, a commitment to climate change and/or social justice. 
 
Pay/Timing: $15/hr. 
Work conditions and project length: Student can be remote or on premises. Commitment is 10-30 hr a week, minimum 10 weeks, up to all summer; continuation into academic year is possible. 
 
To apply please provide a cover letter describing your skills and how they match our requirements, a vita, a link to a LinkedIn or similar URL,  the name and email of one professor who could serve as a reference if contacted.

For QTM Undergraduates

Monday,
April 22, 2024




 
  
 
 
 

 
 
IMPORTANT  ANNOUNCEMENT 
 
The link for the Data Camp access for Summer 2024 and Fall 2024 is updated.  Access new link below. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

NYC Summer Internship Data Engineering Opportunity: APPLY NOW!
 
Role Summary:  Jain Global is looking for a motivated Data Engineering Intern to help enhance and integrate its existing data processing and retrieval systems into its main data platform. The intern will be instrumental in refining the data architecture to support advanced search functionalities and efficient data handling. The role is for a 2-3 summer month in-person internship in NYC.  See ( attached) job description for details.
 
 
See attached PDF flyer for more details 
 
 
Sandra Ruhlman Smith
 
 
 
 
 
Opportunity
 
Seeking Dataverse Developer
 
Background
 
Recovering the US Hispanic Literary Heritage Program (Recovery) at the University of Houston (UH)  
is the largest Hispanic/Latino humanities research program operating in the United States dedicated 
to researching, locating, preserving and making available all literary-historical documents 
produced by Hispanics/Latinos living in the United States from the Colonial Period to 1980. 
 
Recovery is in the process of creating a customized web-based content repository in Dataverse. 
The repository will hold Recovery’s vast archives and metadata (file formats include JPG, TIFF, PNG, PDF,
CSV, Excel, and Word). 
 
It will allow multi-level access to the assets and their metadata to a range of audiences,
Recovery staff, students, researchers, educators and community members. 
The assets will be made discoverable through fully searchable metadata and indexing on search engines. 
The valuable resource will further scholarship and preservation of Latino historical materials 
(1595 to 1980) through the maintenance, modernization, and consolidation of Recovery archival collections. 
 
To learn more about Recovery, please visit: https://artepublicopress.com/recovery-program/ 
Recovery is seeking a developer who can provide customizations and technical support for this effort. This position will implement Dataverse, install software and begin customizations. Customizations to include, but not limited to, developing APIs to accommodate broader search functionalities, bilingual metadata, metadata linking to image files, auto populate features, batch upload features, expanded user roles, and author ownership. 
This position is expected to meet with the project team and UH IT to discuss the customizations needed, establish a workflow, and acquire university technology clearance.  Additionally, this position will assist in determining the cloud storage service that best suits the project’s needs. 
This position will be remote contract work for 2 years.
Required Qualifications
B.S. Computer Science/Computer Engineering or relevant experience in software development and modification
At least 18 months of programming experience 
The ideal candidate for this position should possess the following:
·         Experience working with Humanities data in a university setting
 
·         Experience working with multilingual datasets and user experience
 
·         Ability to communicate technical information to technical and non-technical personnel at various levels in the organization
 
·         Familiarity with research data management systems, databases, and data handling protocols.
 
·         Experience developing custom software solutions for digital asset management systems (DAMS)
 
·         Experience working with Dataverse or similar platforms
 
·         Experience working with cloud storage services such as AWS and Azure
 
·         Experience installing, running apps/services in Linux
 
·         Knowledge of JavaScript, Payara, PostgreSQL, Solr, and jq
 
·         Knowledge of JSON
 
·         Knowledge of APIs
 
Salary: Salary commensurate with education/experience. This is not a benefits eligible position.
Please send the following as PDFs to apprec@central.uh.edu: Cover Letter, Resume, and names and contact information for 2 professional references
We would like to have this position filled by April 30, 2024.

Submitted by Dr. Lorena Gauthereau, University of Houston

For QTM Undergraduates

Tuesday,
April 2, 2024




 
  
 
 
 

 
SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT
Applications are open for QTM Ambassadors for 2024-25
Apply here
2024-25 QTM Ambassadors  Application 
 
 
What is a QTM Ambassador?
 
QTM Ambassadors are an important extension of the QTM department.   They serve as representatives of QTM with its programming and external partners/advisory board and have the opportunity to develop skills that will serve them in future professional capacities. This includes hosting  events, conducting interviews, communicating with professionals, and engaging the community and student body.   The Ambassador cohort will consist of 15-20  currently enrolled Sophomores, Juniors and Seniors who have the following:
 
	•	Must be a QTM major or minor
	•	Have completed at least 3 QTM courses
	•	Have a 3.0 GPA
	•	Have good interpersonal skills
	•	Able to meet on Mondays or Fridays at 4:00 PM bi-weekly
	•	Engage in 1-2 hours/week of support & Activity
	•	Participate for the full academic year
 
What are some of the opportunities and benefits?
	•	Participate in QTM Departmental events like QTM Open House, Faculty & Staff Holiday Party,  DataFest and DataBlitz
	•	Serve as the face of the QTM Department at various events 
	•	Assist with QTM Prep programs
	•	Provide insight and feedback to external advisors, faculty and staff
	•	Conduct panel discussions about the QTM programs and QTM Alumni careers
	•	Develop presentation skills and strengthen interpersonal relationship skills
	•	Have an opportunity to network with external partners, advisory board members and QTM Alumni
	•	Being a part of this group and the experience looks great on your resume/portfolio
	•	Various projects will give you the opportunity to exercise what you have already learned
 
Application as due by April 6th 2024
 
If you are interested in joining this group, please fill out the application below.  We would love for you to be a part of this team.  
 
Website information
https://quantitative.emory.edu/qtm-opportunities/qtm-ambassadors.html
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Emory Undergraduate Medical Review (EUMR)
We are hosting our annual Emotive Arts Series event this Thursday, April 4th, from 6-8 pm in the Campus Life Pavilion. The Emotive Arts Series seeks to synthesize the arts and medicine, and the topic of this year's Emotive Arts series is Nature vs. Nurture, inspired by the theme of our journal this semester for our 10th anniversary: epigenetics.  The event will include a panel featuring various Emory faculty, dance performances, and the presentation of student art and poetry.
We have extended our submission deadline to April 3rd at 11:59PM to allow more students the opportunity to showcase their talents!

MESSAGE FROM Gabrielle Gershon
 
My name is Gabby, and I am a medical student currently working on a research project focused on coronary artery calcium phenotypes and their implications for cardiac risk assessment. We are seeking an undergraduate student with skills in data analytics to join our team and help analyze trends in our patient database. 😊
 
The project aims to evaluate coronary artery calcium phenotypes in a diverse patient population, with the ultimate goal of creating a fair and unbiased method for assessing the risk of adverse cardiac events such as strokes and heart attacks based on coronary artery calcium levels. As a member of our team, you will have the opportunity to work with real-world patient data and contribute to groundbreaking research in the field of cardiology.
 
This position offers the opportunity to earn research for credit, providing valuable experience and enhancing your resume. If you are interested in joining our team, please send your resume to me at gabrielle.gershon@emory.edu
 
Thank you for considering this opportunity. I look forward to potentially working together and discussing the project in more detail.

subject: SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT REGARDING COURSES AND PERMISSION CODES
content:
SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT
 
Many of you may be wondering where is the permission code form  that the department normally sends out prior to registration.  Well, this process has been adjusted and most of the courses offered in Fall 2024 will not need a permission code prior to registering.  In other words, if you have the prerequisite(s) required for that course, you should be able to register for it.   Many of the courses prerequisites have been changed (see below) and the OPUS  has been updated to reflect it.  Therefore,  please read the course description in Atlas.  It will tell you which prerequisites you would need to take that course. If a professor consent is need, please reach out to that professor for approval in order to take that course.  If a permission code is needed please reach out to shanna9@emory.edu. If you have questions regarding the content of a course, please reach out to your QTM and Tracker advisors.   Thanks.

• QTM 350 – (QTM 150 + QTM 151) or CS 170

course requirement

Required” tag require permission code

subject: Special Announcement
content:
SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT
Applications are open for QTM Ambassadors for 2024-25
 
What is a QTM Ambassador?
 
QTM Ambassadors are an important extension of the QTM department.   They serve as representatives of QTM with its programming and external partners/advisory board and have the opportunity to develop skills that will serve them in future professional capacities. This includes hosting  events, conducting interviews, communicating with professionals, and engaging the community and student body.   The Ambassador cohort will consist of 15-20  currently enrolled Sophomores, Juniors and Seniors who have the following:
 
	•	Must be a QTM major or minor
	•	Have completed at least 3 QTM courses
	•	Have a 3.0 GPA
	•	Have good interpersonal skills
	•	Able to meet on Fridays at 4:00 PM bi-weekly
	•	Engage in 1-2 hours/week of support & Activity
	•	Participate for the full academic year
 
What are some of the opportunities and benefits?
	•	Participate in QTM Departmental events like QTM Open House, Faculty & Staff Holiday Party,  DataFest and DataBlitz
	•	Serve as the face of the QTM Department at various events 
	•	Assist with QTM Prep programs
	•	Provide insight and feedback to external advisors, faculty and staff
	•	Conduct panel discussions about the QTM programs and QTM Alumni careers
	•	Develop presentation skills and strengthen interpersonal relationship skills
	•	Have an opportunity to network with external partners, advisory board members and QTM Alumni
	•	Being a part of this group and the experience looks great on your resume/portfolio
	•	Various projects will give you the opportunity to exercise what you have already learned
 
Application as due by April 6th 2024
 
If you are interested in joining this group, please fill out the application below.  We would love for you to be a part of this team.  
 
2024-25 QTM Ambassadors  Application 
 
Best,
 
Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University
Email: shanna9@emory.edu | 470-620-7981
(she/her/hers)

A student-run publication focused on topics at the forefront of science and medicine. We are holding the 2024 Emotive Arts Series, an annual event hosted by EUMR that synthesizes medicine and the arts, and are calling all poets, writers, and artists to consider contributing their work to be showcased at our event! The theme of this spring's journal, in honor of our 10th year anniversary, is epigenetics, and this event will similarly evaluate the effect of nature and nurture on one's health. The event will take place on Thursday, April 4th from 6-8 pm in the Campus Life Pavilion and all submissions will be due by March 31. The New England Statistical Society (NESS - https://nestat.org) is happy to share the NESS NextGen scholarships for underrepresented minorities in statistics and data science. The purpose of these scholarships is to advance the representation of underrepresented groups in statistics and data science by supporting graduating high school seniors and first/second-year undergraduate students who are interested in pursuing a career in statistics and/or data science. 
 
Eligibility: 
·                     Graduating high school senior or first/second-year undergraduate student 
·                     Black, Indigenous or Person of Color (BIPOC) 
·                     Will be enrolled in a U.S. college or university for the upcoming 2024-2025 academic year. 
·                     Shows a genuine interest in statistics and data science through coursework, extracurricular activities, and/or future goals 
A priority will be given for students who are eligible for a Federal Pell Grant Program (for more information, please see this information page from the U.S. Department of Education). 
Deadline: April 15, 2024 
Amount: at least $1,000 
Applications are currently open, apply here: https://nextgenscholarship.nestat.org/

subject: REMINDER - Special Announcement
content:
SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT 
 
2024 Summer AI XPERIENCE
     (applications are now open)
          See below and attached flyer
 
 
Emory University's Center for AI Learning and QTM department are excited to solicit applications from students for the 2024 Summer AI Xperience. In this program, students will work in teams of 5 to complete one of many different data science consulting projects. Each of these projects will contain a mixture of programming and data analysis tasks that will require developing a strong substantive knowledge surrounding the problem.
 
To be selected, students need to:
	•	Have been enrolled in classes at Emory in the Spring 2024 semester and be enrolled at Emory in the Fall 2024 semester.
	•	Be in residence in Atlanta, GA between July 1 and August 15.
	•	Attend 3 or 4 in-person team meetings per week.
	•	Be able to commit roughly 20 hours per week to the project over the 6 week period.
	•	Have knowledge of common statistical analysis and machine learning methods
	•	Have experience programming in R and/or Python:
	◦	Ability to load in and manipulate large data sets
	◦	Ability to clean potentially messy data into workable formats
	◦	Knowledge of common programming control structures 
	◦	Ability to write and debug original functions
	◦	Ability to implement common statistical analysis and machine learning methods
	◦	Ability to read documentation about new methods and implement them
 
Review of applications will begin on March 7, 2024.  However, all applications will be considered if submitted prior to 5:00 PM on March 19, 2024.  Prior to final selection, some students may be asked to do a short in-person interview.  All students will be informed of the status of their application no later than March 21, 2024.
 
Students who are admitted to this program will have the option to participate in exchange for credit. For example, QTM majors and minors who participate may choose to count this experience as 3 credit hours of QTM 498R. QTM 498R may count as a 300+ level elective towards your QTM degree (or as an experiential elective for those on the Data Science track).  Note that most QTM majors/minors may only count one semester of QTM 498R or QTM 495A/495BW towards their degree. We will work with your department's leadership to confirm what course codes are applicable for your experience.
 
Students who choose to take advantage of any of these options will be required to pay the associated tuition. You can notate if you would like to enroll in 3 or 6 credit hours, which would impact whether financial aid could be applied. Unfortunately, our funding model does not allow us to cover this tuition, so paying this will be your responsibility. The tuition cost and information about need-based financial aid can be found at https://oue.college.emory.edu/advising/summer-school/tuition-financial-aid.html.
 
Students will be asked in this survey whether they are interested in counting this program towards an elective course requirement, as opposed to treating this experience as an internship without credit. Students will also be asked about their potential financial plan in order to enroll in the program in this survey.
 
The application for this program can be found here.  If the hyperlink is not working, copy and paste the following link in your browser: https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=nPsE4KSwT0K80DImBtXfOK9f-T_naQBMvN-s-998aalUN0NIR0Q4NzJYNVNXUVlHSUZTUUhaSEI0Wi4u
 
If there are any questions, please do not hesitate to reach out to Dr. Kevin McAlister (kevin.mcalister@emory.edu).  To schedule office hours or advising appointments with Dr. McAlister, please use this booking page.
 
 
 
Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University
Email: shanna9@emory.edu | 470-620-7981
(she/her/hers)

Opportunity
 
STATISTICAL STAFF ANALYST POSITION
 
See attached flyer for details 
 
 
 

 
 
 
Message from
Margaret Corcoran Recruitment  Director  with Green Corps. 
Field School for Environmental Organizing 
 
We are looking for people who are concerned by the state of the environment and who want to do something about it. Our yearlong program has prepared recent college graduates for 30 years to launch a career in environmental  organizing and advocacy by providing hands-on experience running campaigns with groups like the Wilderness Society, Endangered Species Coalition, Mighty Earth and more. We then connect our graduates to jobs in the environmental and social change movement.
 
Green Corps Organizer Program - The Field School for Environmental Organizing
Green Corps is looking for college graduates who are ready to take on the biggest environmental challenges of our day.
Learn more and apply on our website!
 
The planet needs all the help it can get. To win now and build a strong foundation for lasting progress, we need people who know how to organize: to run organizations and campaigns that will inspire the support and action we need to save our environment. Our program starts with intensive classroom training. You learn about issues and campaigns, organizing theory and principles, and skills from recruiting volunteers to staging a media event. Then, you move to a more hands-on experience. You make a difference on important campaigns to transition our country to clean energy, protect wildlife, and more. For example, Lauren Karpinski, an organizer from the Green Corps Class of 2019, brought together a coalition of 40 groups that helped win a landmark solar energy bill in Arkansas.
 
We’re accepting the top 20 candidates for our 2024-2025 program. Graduates will join our more than 400 alumni who are leading environmental campaigns and organizations across the country. If you’re passionate about the environment and ready to learn and practice the craft of organizing after graduation, apply today!
 
Not a graduating senior? Add your name to our list to receive updates about Green Corps including summer internships and jobs in the environmental and broader social change field!
 
Green Corps’ year-long program begins in August 2024 with introductory classroom training, and continues with field placements in multiple locations across the U.S. Candidates must be willing to relocate. Please contact Margaret Corcoran at margaret@greencorps.org with additional questions.
 
Green Corps is part of The Public Interest Network, which operates and supports organizations committed to a shared vision of a better world and a  strategic approach to social change. Visit publicinterestnetwork.org to learn more. Green Corps is an equal opportunity employer. The target annual compensation for this position is $32,500 (but compensation may range between $32,500 and $39,000 depending on location). Green Corps' benefits package includes medical insurance for employees and dependents, needs-based student loan assistance, commuter benefit program, sick pay (60-72 hours/year depending on location), and 80 hours (2 weeks) of accrued vacation. We also offer short-term positions, an excellent training program, and opportunities for advancement.
 
Need more information contact her at (617) 901-6114.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
LUNCH & LEARN
 
The Emory Center for Digital Scholarship (ECDS) and the Envisioning Baroque Rome digital humanities project invite you for a one-hour round-table Lunch & Learn at noon on Thursday, March 21st in Woodruff Library.
Enjoy a provided lunch while the project team discusses the process of building a 3D model of the city of Rome. Envisioning Baroque Rome began in 2013 with the goal of rebuilding Rome in 1676 according to the map of that year, Nuova piante et alzata della città di Roma, and other prints by artist Giovanni Battista Falda. Led by Sarah McPhee, Samuel Candler Dobbs Professor of Art History, the round-table will include ECDS staff Joanna Mundy, Ian Burr, and John Halbert, and artist Nicole Costello Matthews. The team will discuss the research, modeling, texturing, and animation of Baroque Rome, and you will have an opportunity to explore the newest version of the 3D city yourself!
 
Learn about the recent research in the project and stroll the streets of Rome with Giovanni Battista Falda.
 
We hope that you are able to attend. To RSVP, fill out this form by Monday, March 18th. If you have any questions, please email Joanna Mundy (jcmundy@emory.edu).
 
Submitted by Joanna Mundy

ALL GRADUATING SENIORS - PLEASE FORWARD YOUR DEGREE TRACKER SUMMARY REPORT TO shanna9@emory.edu FOR GRADUATION CLEARANCE WITH THE QTM DEPARTMENT  before 2/12/2024.  Thanks. 
 
 
 
 
 
ANNOUNCEMENT
 
 
Emory Center for Digital Scholarship's Spring 2024 Workshop Schedule  
(All Classes are Wednesdays, 1-2pm, on Zoom.) 
 
February 7
Text-Based Video Editing with Adobe Premiere
February 14
Text Mining in the HathiTrust Digital Library

To get the Zoom link, please RSVP using our calendar. If you have any questions, email ECDS (ecds@emory.edu). You can also also visit our catalogue of past workshops on our new updated Scholarblogs site or take our survey to tell us what you’d like to see in future workshops!

OPPORTUNITY
 
Ringle is a company that provides undergraduate and graduate students with the opportunity to teach English to Korean students. Ringle’s mission is to break down language barriers and allow its members to exchange knowledge and help each other grow.
 
We are seeking talented individuals to join our team and teach English to students around the world! We are looking for tutors with a wide variety of backgrounds and interests from top universities like Emory University.
·         No past teaching experience necessary but native-level fluency in English is required
·         The position is super flexible with NO minimum working hours - You make your own schedule!
·         Ringle provides all the pre-made lesson materials for you 
·         The position is fully remote through the Ringle interface and Zoom
·         Starting rate is $9.50 for a 20-minute lesson and $17 for a 40-minute lesson with additional bonuses and promotions available
 
I have really enjoyed my own time as a Ringle tutor and value the opportunity to connect with students around the world. If you have any questions, please feel free to email me at spandana.amirneni@emory.edu, and please click this link to sign up if interested! 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
MAKE AN IMPACT. YOUR OWN WAY. SPRING LEADERSHIP PROGRAMS 
 
Oliver Wyman Management consulting  is hosting two in-person programs for undergraduate students in the Classes of 2025 and 2026 focusing on relationship building and professional development for students exploring the consulting profession. Session topics include preparing for case interviews, leadership spotlights, and more! Students who complete either program will be invited to interview for a full-time or internship role.
 
 EST Women’s Leadership Series March 7th & 8th 2024 | Dallas, TX-  Application deadline Sunday, February 4th 2024 at 11:59 pm EST  
Diversity Leadership Summit April 18th & 19th 2024 | New York, NY -Application deadline Sunday, March 10th 2024 at 11:59 pm EST
 
 
QTM alumna, Carissa Caccia has shared the program information with QTM for any qualified students that might be interested. If there are any questions students are invited to email her directly at Carissa.caccia@oliverwyman.com. 
 
 
Submitted by Sandra  Ruhlman Smith
